projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A DISCOURSE Touching the Inconveniencies of a Long continued Parliament.
AND THE IVDGEMENT OF THE LAW OF THE LAND In that Behalfe.
By DAVID JENKINS now Pri≈øoner in the Tower of LONDON.

June 17th
Printed in the Yeare, 1647.

div.head: A DISCOURSE Touching the Inconveniencies of a Long continued Parliament.

list.item: 1. A Perpetuall Parliament is repugnant to the Act made this Parliament for a Trienniall Parliament; for how can every three years a Paliament begin, if this be perpetuall, which may be ≈øo if the two Hou≈øes plea≈øe?
2. An adjournment of the Parliament makes no Se≈ø≈øion, 4 Pars, In≈øtitut. fol. 27. Howbeit, before the Adjournment, the King gives His Royall a≈ø≈øent to ≈øome Bills. Cooke, ibid.
3. There is no Se≈ø≈øion till a prorogation or di≈ø≈øolution of the Parliament.

4. This Parliament, as appeares by the Act for not di≈ø≈øolvirg thereof, ≈øet downe in the Printed Statutes of this Parliament, fol. 138. cannot be prorogued but by Act of Parliament. There hath beene as yet no Act of Parliament pre≈øent, and therefore all the Acts of this Parliament, are Acts of one Se≈ø≈øion.

5. All the Acts of one Se≈ø≈øion relate to the fir≈øt day of the Parliament, Plowd com. 79 35 H. 8. Bro. relation 35. Bro. Parl. 86. Dier. 1 Mariae 45. and all the Acts of ≈øuch a Parliament are Acts of one day; ≈øo the Act for the Trienniall, and the Act for this Perpetuall, are two Acts of one day by the Law.

6. 4 Ed. 3. cap. and 36 Ed. 3. cap. 10. A Parliament is to bee holden once every yeere, and more often if need ≈øhall bee; tho≈øe Acts are confirmed by the Act for the Trienniall Parliament. How doth a perpetuall Parliament agree with a Parliament once every yeere, or with the intention of tho≈øe Lawes? How doth a Parliament every three yeers agree with a Parliament for ever, which may be, if the two Hou≈øes plea≈øe?

7. The re≈øult is this; at one day in Law this Parliament two Acts have pa≈ø≈øed (for howbeit the one was in 16 Carol. and the other in 17. Carol. yet both in Law are Acts of one day) the one ≈øaith there ≈øhall be a Trienniall Parliament after the end of the ≈øitting of this Parliament: The other, this Parliament ≈øhall ≈øit for ever, if they plea≈øe. The one will have a Parliament with an end, the other, a Parliament without an end.

div.p: When an Act of Parliament is again≈øt common right or Rea≈øon, 8 Pars, Doct. Bonhams ca≈øe fol. 118. 8 Ed. 3.30. 33 E. 3. ce≈ø≈øavit, 32. 27. H.G. Annuity 41. 14 Eliz. Dier, 313. or repugnant, or impo≈ø≈øible to bee performed, the Common Law ≈øhall controle it, and adjudge this Act to bee void; they are the words of the Law.
An Act of Parliament, that a man ≈øhall bee Judge in his owne-cau≈øe, is a void Act.

Begin with Common Right. It is again≈øt Common Right, that indebted men ≈øhould not pay their debts: That if any Member of the Hou≈øe of CoÃÑmons doe any Subject wrong by di≈ø≈øei≈øing him of his land, or di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing him of his goods, or bla≈øting of his fame, or doing violence to
his per≈øon, that ≈øuch per≈øons during their lives ≈øhould not bee que≈øtioned by a priviledge of Parliament, and that extended al≈øo to many others be≈øides them≈øelves. Common Right doth abhorre the≈øe enormities, which a perpetuall Paliament doth beget, be≈øides the utter de≈øtruction of all mens actions, reall, per≈øonall, or mixt, who have to doe with Parliament men, 21 Jac. by the Statute of Limitation, which confines ≈øuits to certain yeares.

For Common Rea≈øon. Parliaments were ordained for remedies to redre≈ø≈øe publike grievances; It is again≈øt Rea≈øon they ≈øhould make publike and in≈øufferable grievances. The Law of the Land allowes no protection for any man imployed in the ≈øervice of the Kingdome but for a yeare, to be free from ≈øuits, and in many ≈øuits none at all, howbeit hee be in ≈øuch ≈øervice; 39 H. 6.39. but a Parliament perpetuall may prove a protection, not for a yeare, but for ever, which is again≈øt all manner of Rea≈øon.

For Impo≈ø≈øibility. The death of His Maje≈øty (who≈øe life God prolong) di≈ø≈øolves it nece≈ø≈øarily; For the Writ of ≈øummons is, Carolus Rex in hoc individuo, and Carolus Rex is in this particular, Habiturus colloquium & tractatum cum Prelatis & proceribus, &c. 2 H. 5. Cooke Title Parliam 3. pars. King Charles being to have Conference and Treaty with his Prelates and Peeres; Carolus Rex cannot have Colloquium & tractatum, Conference and Treaty, when he is decea≈øed; and therefore it is impo≈ø≈øible for any Parliament to continue as long as they plea≈øe, as for a Parliament to make a dead man alive.
For Repugnancie. That which is but for a time, cannot be affirmed to have continuance for ever, it is repugnant.

The end of the Act of 17. Caroli Regis, which is to continue at plea≈øure, is in the ≈øaid Act expre≈ø≈øed to be to rai≈øe credit for money for the≈øe three purpo≈øes. Fir≈øt, for reliefe of his Maje≈øties Army and people in the North.
Secondly, for preventing the iminent danger of the Kingdome, Thirdly, for ≈øupply of other His Maje≈øties pre≈øent and urgent occa≈øions. The≈øe ends are ended, the reliefe of that Army, the iminent danger ≈øuppo≈øed was ≈øixe yeares agoe, the ≈øupply of His Maje≈øtie hath beene a ≈øupply again≈øt him, take away the end, the meanes thereto are to no purpo≈øe, take away the cau≈øe, the effect cea≈øeth; and therefore the three ends of this Act being determined, Sir Anthony Mayns ca≈øe. 5. pars, 1 H. 4.6. Littl. cap. Villen. it agreeth with Law and Rea≈øon, the Act ≈øhould end, the Law rejects things unprofitable and u≈øele≈ø≈øe.

A perpetuall Parliament (be≈øides that it incites men to ≈øelfe-ends, de≈øtructive of the publique of which the whole Kingdome hath had ≈øufficient experience) wilbe a con≈øtant charge to the Kingdome; for that every County and Borough, who ≈øend Members to the Parliament, are by the Law to pay wages to their Parliament men, which to many Counties will amount above ≈øome Sub≈øidies Yearely: There are many poore Borough-Townes in each County of this Kingdome, who being to maintaine two Burge≈ø≈øes in Parliament, will be quickly begger'd, if the Parliament have no end; for all which rea≈øons it is cleare, that ≈øuch long continuance of Parliaments, will in≈øtead of a remedy (which is and ought to be the proper and true end of Parliaments) become an in≈øufferable grievance and oppre≈ø≈øion to all the People of the Land.

The Writ of Summons this Parliament is the ba≈øts and foundation of the Parliament. If the Foundation be de≈øtroyed the Parliament fals. The A≈ø≈øembly of Parliament if for thre purpo≈øes. Rex e≈øt habiturus colloquium et tractatum cumpraelatis, magnatibus et proceribus ≈øuper arduis negotijs, concernentibus, 1. Nos. 2 Defen≈øionem regni no≈øtri 3. Defen≈øionom Eccle≈øiae Anglicanae. This Parliament hath overthrowne this Foundation in all 3 parts, 1. Nos. the King, they have cha≈øed him away, and impri≈øoned
him; they have voted no prelats, and a number of other Lords, about 40. in the City mu≈øt not come to the Hou≈øe, and about 40. more are out of Towne, the colloquium et tractatus are made void therby. For the King cannot con≈øult and treat there with men removed from thence. 2. Defen≈øionem regni no≈øtri, that is gone; they have made it their Kingdome, not His, for they have u≈øurped all his Soveraigntie. 3. Defen≈øionem Eccle≈øiae Anglicana, that is gone, that Eccle≈øia Anglicana mu≈øt be under≈øtood nece≈ø≈øarily that Church, that at the te≈øte of of the Writ was Eccle≈øiae Anglicana, they have de≈øtroyed that too. So now the≈øe men would be called a Parliament, having abated, qua≈øhed, and made nothing of the Writ whereby they were Summoned and A≈ø≈øembled. If the Writ be made void, all the proce≈ø≈øe is void al≈øo: that Hou≈øe mu≈øt needs fall, where the Foundation is overthrowne, Subato fundamento opus cadit, the Foundation being taken away, the worke falls, is both a maxime in Law and Rea≈øon.

For ≈øome yeares pa≈øt, there is no crime from Trea≈øon to Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe, but they are guilty of: all Trea≈øon, Felonies, Robberies, tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes are contra pacem, coronam et dignitatem Regis, again≈øt the Peace, Crowne and Dignitie of the King; as appeares by all Indictments in all Ages. Pax Regis the Kings Peace, Corona Regis, the Kings Crowne, Dignitas Regis, the Kings Dignitie, are all trod under foot, and made nothing; Pax Regis, the Peace of the King is become a Warre again≈øt the King, His Dignitie put into pri≈øon, and the Crowne put upon their owne heads.

All the Judges of England have re≈øolved, Nevills ca≈øe 7. part, 34. 2. Jacobi. that Noblemen committing Trea≈øon have forfeited their Office and Dignitie, their Office is to councell the King in time of Peace, to defend him in time of Warre, and therefore tho≈øe men again≈øt the duty and end of their Dignitie taking not onely Councell, but Armes al≈øo to de≈øtroy
Him, and being thereof attaint by due cour≈øe of Law by a tacite condition annexed to the e≈øtate of their Dignitie, have forfeited the ≈øame; they are the words of the Law, and therefore they have made them≈øelves incapable to be Members of the upper Hou≈øe.

div.head: The Oppre≈ø≈øions of the People.
div.p: Briberies, Extortions, Monopolies, ought to be inquired after by the Hou≈øe of Commons, and complained of to the King and Lords, what have they done?

The Hou≈øe of Commons cannot by the Law commit any man to pri≈øon, who is not of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe, for Trea≈øon, Murder, or Felony, or any thing but for the di≈øturbance of the publique Peace, by the priviledge of the whole body.

They have no power by the Writ, which the King i≈ø≈øueth to elect and returne Members of that Hou≈øe, ≈øo to doe. For the Writ for them is onely ad faciendum et con≈øentiendum to tho≈øe things, whereof His Maje≈øtie ≈øhall con≈øult and treat with his Prelates and Nobles, et de communi con≈øilio Regni ≈øhall be there ordained, as appeares by the Writ. Here is no ≈øeparate power given over the Kings people to them, but onely ad faciendum et con≈øentiendum, 4 Pars. in≈øtitut. 23.24.25. and in all times this hath beene expounded and re≈øtrained to that which concerned their owne Members in Relation to the publique Service, as he is a Member of the corporate body of the Parliament, wherof the King is the Head.

But that the Hou≈øe of Commons have committed any man for Trea≈øon, Murder or Felony, or for any offence that had no relation to a Member of the Hou≈øe of Commons, as it is again≈øt Law and Rea≈øon, ≈øo no in≈øtance can be given till this Parliament. 19 H. 6.43.22. E. 4.22. 5 H. 4. cap. 8. 3 H. 6.46.

All Que≈øtions and trials where witne≈ø≈øe are examined, the examination is upon oath by the Law, by all our
Bookes, Statutes, every dayes practice. Examination without an Oath, is but a loo≈øe di≈øcour≈øe; therefore the Hou≈øe of Commons not claiming power to give an Oath, have no power to examine any man.

No man ≈øhall bee impri≈øoned by the King or His Councell, unle≈ø≈øe it be by Inditement, 25 E. 3. c. 4. Perition of Right. 3 Car. pre≈øentment of his good and lawfull Neighbours where ≈øuch deeds bee done, in due manner, or by proce≈ø≈øe made by Wtit originall at the Common Law: This Statute rehear≈øes Magna Charta, pag. 29. and expounds Lex terrae, the Law of the Land there mentioned: This Law binds all men, and the Hou≈øe of Commons (for they ≈øay they are of the Kings Councell) in all points, but onely again≈øt the di≈øturbers of the ≈øervice of the Parliament; and therefore the impri≈øonment of ≈øeverall per≈øons who are not their Members, and for no di≈øturbance to their Members, is utterly again≈øt the Law of the Land, and the franchi≈øe of the Free-men of this Realme.
Cui non licet quod minus, non licet quod majus; he who may not doe what is le≈ø≈øe, may not doe what is greater; they cannot commit a man for murder or Felony, much le≈ø≈øe for Trea≈øon.

No Court can fine and impri≈øon, 8 Pars, Cook 120. 27 H. 6.8. but a Court of Record, the Hou≈øe of Commons is no Court of Record, the Hou≈øe of the Lords where the King is in his Per≈øon, his Nobles and his Judges, and Councell at Law, the Ma≈øters of the Chancery a≈ø≈øi≈øting, is a Court of Record, and that is the Court of Parliament, where the colloquium & tractatus is. The Hou≈øe of Commons may pre≈øent grievances, grant or not grant aydes, con≈øent or not con≈øent to new lawes, but for fining and impri≈øoning any but as afore≈øaid, is but of a late date, and no ancient u≈øage: They have no Journall Booke, but ≈øithence Edw. 6. time. 6 Hen. 8. cap. 15. doth not prove the Hou≈øe of Commons to be a Court of Record, it mentions onely to be entered on Record in the Booke of the Clerke of the Parliament, if any Member depart into the Country.
There is no Journall there but ≈øithence Ed. 6. time, or it is a remembrance or memoriall, as 12 H. 4.23.

The whole Parliament is one corporate body, 14 H. 8.3. 36 H. 8. Dier 60. 4 Pars In≈øtit. c ‚Ä¢ p. 1. con≈øi≈øting of the Head and three E≈øtates: The Court is only there where the Con≈øilium & tractatus is, where the con≈øult and treaty is with the King, which is in the Hou≈øe of Lords onely.

The Hou≈øe of Commons claime not to examine upon oath any man; no Court can bee without a power to give an oath, Courts Baron, Court of Pipowders, County-Court, may and doe give oath: No Court can bee without a power to try, no tryall can be without Oath; and therefore the Hou≈øe of Commons not claiming power to give an Oath, can bring no matter to tryall, and con≈øequently can be no Court.

The behaviour of the Commons at a Conference with the Lords, the Commons are alwayes uncovered, and ≈øtanding when the Lords ≈øit with their hats on, which ≈øhewes they are not Colleagues in judgement, for fellow Judges owe no ≈øuch Reverence to their Companions.

When was ever Fine impo≈øed by the Hou≈øe of Commons e≈øtreated in the Exchequer? 11 H. 4. ca. 1. The ejecting of a Member, who hath ≈øitten, is again≈øt the Law; for they cannot remove a man out of the Hou≈øe unduly returned, much le≈ø≈øe a man returned duely.

By the≈øe Lawes it appeares,
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ H. 4. cap. 1. 1 H 5. cap. 1. 8 H. 6. cap. 7. 23 H. 6. cap. 15 that if any undue returne be made, the per≈øon returned is to continue a Member, the Sheriffes puni≈øhment is 200. pound, one to the King, another to the party that is duly elected, impri≈øonment for a yeare without Baile or Mainpri≈øe; and that per≈øon who is unduly returned, ≈øhall ≈øerve at his owne charge, and have no benefit at the end of the Parliament by the Writ De ≈øolutione foendorum Militum, Civium & Burgen≈øium Parliament. and the tryall of the fal≈øity of the returne, is to be before the Ju≈øtices of A≈ø≈øi≈øes in the proper
County, or by action of debt in any Court of Record. This condemnes the Committee for undue elections, which hath been practi≈øed but of late times; 3 Ed. 4.20. 5 Ed. 4.41. for be≈øides the≈øe Lawes, it is again≈øt a maxime of the Common law; an averment is not receivable again≈øt the returne of the Sheriffe, for his returne is upon Oath, which Oath is to be credited in that ≈øuit wherein the returne is made.

The ≈øaid Statutes condemne and make tho≈øe members no members, which were not re≈øiant in the County or Boroughs, for which they were elected, at the time of the te≈øt of the Writ of the Summons of the Parliament, and any abu≈øive practice of late times to the contrary is again≈øt the Law, and ought not to be allowed.

div.head: A≈ø≈øault upon Parliament Men.
div.p: If a Par ‚Ä¢ iament man or his Meniall Servant be a≈ø≈øaulted, beaten, or wounded, in the Parliament time, 5 H. 4. cap 6. 11 H. 6. cap 11. proclamation ≈øhall bee made where the deed is done, that the offender ≈øhall render him≈øelfe to the Kings Bench, within a quarter of a yeare after proclamation made, and the offence there to be tryed, for default of appearance the offender is declared, attainted of the mi≈ødeed, and it is accorded that thereafter it bee done likewi≈øe in the like Ca≈øe.
Serving of proce≈ø≈øe upon a Lord of the Parliament puni≈øhed in the Lords Hou≈øe. Bogo de Clare 18 E. 3.4 pars, In≈øtit. fol. 24. Iohn Thorn≈øbyes ca≈øe, Clerk of the Parliam, ibid. 10. E. ‚Ä¢ .
Serving of proce≈ø≈øe upon Thornsby inquired of in the Chancery, and there the offenders were convicted.
The premi≈ø≈øes prove, that breaches of priviledge of Parliament may bee puni≈øhed el≈øewhere then in Parliament.

Upon all this Di≈øcour≈øe, it is ea≈øie to di≈øcerne what fruits may be expected from this Parliament, continuing as long as the two Hou≈øes plea≈øe; and that there is no ≈øafety for this Common-wealth, but by the Ob≈øervations of their ancient Franchi≈øes, Cu≈øtomes and Lawes.

div.head: CONCLUSION.
div.p: I Say againe, that without an Act of Oblivion, a gracious generall Pardon from His Majesty, the Arreares of the Souldiers paid, a favorable regard had to tender Con≈øciences, there will bee neither Truth nor Peace in this Land, nor any man ≈øecure of any thing he hath.
